body: Umm jinja is unicode based so if operations involving unicode strings fail that's a bug. Having two types of strings in jinja makes no sense.
@torfsen That sounds reasonable, especially if there is a global way to enable unicodeliterals so that everything is just treated that way.

This is actually a "bug" with `.format` which does not support string coercion on Python 2.  We intentionally do not issue string literals as unicode literals on python 2 if they are in the ASCII range as APIs traditionally use coercion on it.  I would file this as a bug against Python and not Jinja :)

When they introduced `.format` in Python 2 they applied Python 3 semantics on it. This does not work well with how Jinja is structured.  I don't think I can do anything about this without breaking other code that requires bytestrings.

Traditionally `datetime.strftime` could not at all work with unicode strings for instance.  Maybe we can slowly relax that requirement but there are still lots of apis that break when unicode data is passed on 2.x

``` python
>>> '%s' % u'\N{SNOWMAN}'
u'\u2603'
>>> '{}'.format(u'\N{SNOWMAN}')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\u2603' in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)
```

So should this be closed as a "can't fix"? Or does a note need to be added to the docs somewhere about this?

> As a workaround you can use the `format` filter instead. However, it seems that it only supports the old (Python 2) string formatting syntax.

FYI--the current plan (open to input) is to deprecate the `format` filter, see: https://github.com/pallets/jinja/issues/566
@jeffwidman note that `%` does the same thing anyways.

issue.title: str vs. unicode

repository.name: ckan
repository.description: CKAN is an open-source DMS (data management system) for powering data hubs and data portals. CKAN makes it easy to publish, share and use data. It powers catalog.data.gov, open.canada.ca/data, data.humdata.org among many other sites.

issue.body:
In Python 2, `__repr__` and `__str__` must return instances of `str`. Returning `unicode` instances fails:

```
Python 2.7.6 (default, Jun 22 2015, 18:00:18) 
[GCC 4.8.2] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> class Foo(object):
...     def __str__(self): return u'ö'
...     def __repr__(self): return u'ö'
... 
>>> str(Foo())
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xf6' in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)
>>> repr(Foo())
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xf6' in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)
```

I ran into this problem on my CKAN 2.5.2 installation due to tags containing non-ASCII characters, because `model.Tag.__repr__` [looks like this](https://github.com/ckan/ckan/blob/master/ckan/model/tag.py#L215):

```
def __repr__(self):
    return '<Tag %s>' % self.name
```

That expression will return either a `str` or a `unicode` instance, depending on the type of `self.name`.

I tried to fix that (and similar) errors by making sure that all implementations of `__repr__` and `__str__` always return `str` and `__unicode__` always returns `unicode`. However, while they do enforce the correct behavior, these fixes break a lot of other pieces of code which (implicitly) assumed the old behavior.

The problem is that there seems to be no rule whether `str` or `unicode` are to be used in a given context. Therefore, each part of the code which does string processing and object-to-string conversion needs to make sure it handles both `str` and `unicode` correctly. The errors that pop up after I fixed `__repr__`, etc. show that this is often not done correctly.

Before spending a lot of time fixing each of these little issues I want to make sure that I'm on the right track concerning how Unicode is handled in CKAN. Correct handling of Unicode in Python 2 is a non-trivial issue, and in my opinion CKAN would benefit greatly from a clear strategy. This is especially true with regard to an eventual migration to Python 3. In particular:
- What encoding should CKAN Python source files use (see [PEP 263](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0263/))?
- Do we want to use `unicode_literals` from [`__future__`](https://docs.python.org/2/library/__future__.html)?
- Do we use `str` or `unicode` internally?
- In what form do we pass/receive strings to/from Pylons, babel, the file system, etc.?

Are there existing CKAN conventions with regard to this? The documentation only mentions Unicode in a few isolated places.

issue.title: ui: fixed encoding issues

repository.name: cds-videos
repository.description: Access articles, reports and multimedia content in HEP

issue.body:
- fixed UnicodeEncodeError on record details view when keywords contains
non ASCII chars.
- fixed deposit ui which fails when searching for keywords with non
ASCII chars.
- removed all dangerous .format() from Jinja2 templates because it
breaks when formatting unicode strings
- See: https://github.com/pallets/jinja/issues/392
- addresses #1332
